pr_title: Eager Interleaved support added to a @Query annotation (#2165)

+	 * Otherwise an SQL will be wrapped to eager-load lists with {@link Interleaved#lazy()} equals fo "false".

+	boolean fetchInterleaved() default false;

replies.bodyText:
Well, it still not a perfect name. I hear it like "fetchAnyInterleavedAlwaysEagerly". And the fetchInterleavedEagerly is still a very long name.
In the worst situation, any interleaved will be proxied and lazy-fetched in any case.
How about to rename it to eagerFetch? it sounds like - by default we have a lazy-fetch but we can enable eager-fetch when needed.
"There are only two hard things in Computer Science: cache invalidation and naming things."
-- Phil Karlton
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText: I'm OK with fetchInterleaved. I would just ask to create an integration test that uses @Query(.... fetchInterleaved=true) directly on an actual repository.
replies.author: meltsufin

timeline.bodyText: move " " + persistentEntity.tableName() to the line where you initialize final String subquery, then you could just use .append(subquery) here
timeline.author: dmitry-s
dmitry-s

replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText: I see, makes sense
replies.author: dmitry-s

timeline.bodyText:
The test fails on line 279 - the "lazy-fetch" is not work as expected (as it was before merge PR #2132) and the t.getSubTrades() returns an empty collection. Is it OK?
The Mockito.verify on line 280 also fails - a "lazy-load-logic" is not invoked.
I did a separate local branch from rev 26e9adf and run a similar test against it.
In that brach, the followed test passed fine
		Mockito.clearInvocations(spannerTemplate);
		assertThat(tradeRepository.fetchByIdLazy(aTrade.getId()))
				.isNotEmpty()
				.hasValueSatisfying(t -> assertThat(t.getId()).isEqualTo(aTrade.getId()))
				.hasValueSatisfying(t -> assertThat(t.getTraderId()).isEqualTo(aTrade.getTraderId()))
				.hasValueSatisfying(t -> assertThat(t.getSymbol()).isEqualTo(aTrade.getSymbol()))
				.hasValueSatisfying(t -> assertThat(t.getSubTrades()).hasSize(aTrade.getSubTrades().size()));
		Mockito.verify(spannerTemplate, Mockito.times(2))
				.executeQuery(any(Statement.class), any());
		Mockito.verify(spannerTemplate, Mockito.times(1))
				.query(eq(Trade.class), any(Statement.class), any(SpannerQueryOptions.class));
I think the PR #2132 did a bug with @query annotation.
Will try to find & fix it with next commits
timeline.author: s13o

replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText:
Good catch. How do you think that can be fixed?
Maybe we should nullify the laze loaded fields on the parent entity retrieval?
replies.author: dmitry-s

replies.bodyText:
I've tried to tell about this problem we could potentially have before but my Eng is not so fluent to be clear, sorry.
I have no clever idea yet :(
I think the most strong solution could be to have some additional flag in aspannerPersistentProperty that it has been populated already.
"nulling" of fields is not a good idea - the field could be created by Lombok builder and it could be a business logic (like enty-to-json transformers) that expect the field can never be null
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText: Discussing with @dmitry-s offline, he pointed out that it would just be null until someone tries to access it, at which point it will be lazy-loaded. So, no one should ever see it as null.
replies.author: meltsufin

replies.bodyText:
It sounds like a hack.
What the next step should be? Are we going to merge this PR and will do a fix later or we can collaborate somehow in another way?
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText: I will add a fix in this branch.
replies.author: dmitry-s

replies.bodyText: so few I know about the GitHub : (
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText: Sorry, my test was wrong. You are right, it is because of the default value.
replies.author: dmitry-s

replies.bodyText: in theory, we can to some "magic proxy" for each interleaved ... but it seems to be too complex to be stable
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText:
we can do a very simple decision - if the code reached line 593 of SpannerTemplate line it means that any eager-interleaved is already fetched so any other should be a proxy for "lazy-interleaved"
I think the only scenario when it is not true - it is @query(fetchInterleaved=false)
Is not it?
Probably I'm wrong...
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText:
in my implementation of PR #2132 I built an SQL-query (ResultSet) and a function to process it at the same time in parallel - it was a "pair". So when I'm started to process RS I had only to invoke a function.
Your PR is much simple so it is better, but there is a single place here where it is difficult to understand which fields are populated already.
I don't understand how this magic method works (ConverterAwareMappingSpannerEntityProcessor#mapToList(com.google.cloud.spanner.ResultSet, java.lang.Class, java.util.Set<java.lang.String>, boolean))
entityReader.read(entityClass,
	resultSet.getCurrentRowAsStruct(),
	includeColumns,
	allowMissingColumns)

And I can't propose any solution yet :(
But this method is a good place to mark any Interleaved as 'populated' at processing of it
replies.author: s13o

timeline.bodyText: Could you clarify what is this method for?
timeline.author: dmitry-s

replies.bodyText:
The method name is probably bad, but...
The initial idea of interleaved eager-fetching was to use wrapped query SELECT *, <interlieved-sub-select> FROM (<initial query>) in the same way as the method applySort at line 160. It was fine until we decided to use the fetchInterleaved as permanently true. After a number of failed integration tests and attempts to fix them, I understood that the wrapped query will not work in general. Mainly because of Spanner does not preserve sort ordering of wrapped queries.
Then I concluded - when the user has created an SQL with a complete list of fields to select it is not really good idea to add some more fields with additional sub-selects - it could really affect performance to select fields that were not requested. But when the query is like "select * from Table ..." - it is the best candidate to split it into two parts an add interleaved fields into the middle. Like "select *, " + <interlieved> + " from Table ..." and it does not break any skip\limit or sorting conditions.
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText:
I don't really like that we have to rely on SELECT_ALL_PATTERN, there could be cases where it doesn't work and that would lead to inconsistent behavior. It is not transparent and would be hard to detect.
Is there a way to avoid regex matching? What if we use joins instead of sub-queries?
replies.author: dmitry-s

replies.bodyText:
To clarify, the query I'm thinking about would be something like that:
SELECT    singers.*,
          array_agg(struct(albumid, albumtitle, array
          (
                 select as struct *
                 FROM   songs
                 WHERE  songs.singerid = albums.singerid
                 AND    songs.albumid = albums.albumid))) AS albums
FROM      (
                 SELECT *
                 FROM   singers
                 WHERE  singerid = 1) AS singers
LEFT JOIN albums
ON        albums.singerid = singers.singerid
GROUP BY  singers.singerid,
          singers.name 
LIMIT      10
OFFSET     30 

where SELECT * FROM   singers WHERE  singerid = 1 is the user-provided query.
What do you think about that approach?
replies.author: dmitry-s

replies.bodyText:
I understood
It looks more complex but the main - it is not clear how to process such resultset
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText: the new version is better :)
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText:
here we have original SQL as a source for a new query - it is pointed in "... FROM (SELECT * FROM   singers WHERE  singerid = 1)".
But the sort order of such SQL is not preserved
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText: Does it preserve order in current implementation? I believe we wrap the user-provided query in SELECT * FROM (<query>) LIMIT .. OFFSET ..
replies.author: dmitry-s
s13o

replies.bodyText: We really wrap the user-provided queries by SELECT * FROM (<query>) LIMIT .. OFFSET ... We doing it ONLY when we have a SpannerPageableQueryOptions parameter - in such case any "sorting" from it will overwrite the pointed by the SQL itself. And we should at least specify it in the documentation I believe.
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText: I think we should just accept the fact that the sort order in custom @Querys will not be preserved. The solutions is to pass in the sort order in the Pageable argument. This is definitely something that needs to be in our refdoc.
replies.author: meltsufin

replies.bodyText:
@s13o I think it's ok if ordering is not preserved. We apply ordering from Pageable, and that's how it should be passed.
Could you roll back changes that introduced regexp?
I think after that we should be able to merge this PR.
Thanks
replies.author: dmitry-s

replies.bodyText:
oops, will try
but I'll have to change the test SpannerRepositoryIntegrationTests#queryMethodsTest line ~ 192
replies.author: s13o
s13o

replies.bodyText:
Sounds good. The sort order should be determined by the Pageable that is passed to the method. That is:
PageRequest.of(2, 2, org.springframework.data.domain.Sort.by(Order.asc("id")))

lines 188-189
replies.author: dmitry-s

replies.bodyText:
but you didn't answer me about the regex.
You probably don't like Pearl :)
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText: I need to have it merged so I'll revert the regex, but, please your opinion is very important to me.
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText:
@s13o We avoid parsing the SQL in principle. Experience has taught us that it's a rather risky option. Even augmenting queries is risky, but we decided to go with it in the absence of better alternatives.
For example, note that Spanner SQL may contain query hints. That's one situation where parsing can fall apart.
replies.author: meltsufin

replies.bodyText: @s13o You don't have to merge it to undo a commit. I think git revert <commit hash> should do the trick.
replies.author: dmitry-s

replies.bodyText:
You goddamn right. I also hated the idea to parse the SQL from the beginning but saw no other alternative to satisfy failed IT tests.
Many thanks for the beautiful explanation.
replies.author: s13o
s13o
